comment.body: This is why #Bitcoin and the #Zeronet's of the world are so important now. The people must get more involved in the micro management of their countries and the world. They must assume fine grained participation in all aspects of the political management of their countries. This has not been possible until now. The Facebook's and Twitter's of the world have been eager participants in the exploitation of the masses for the benefit of the few..ğŸ‘ğŸ˜ Also we need to aggressively start the implementation of various modalities of mesh networking #smartphones. Our phones should do more than just sit around spying on us most of the time. #Zeronet is the perfect mesh net application, and has huge potential. If you build it they'll come...ğŸ‘ğŸ˜€

@ulrichard: me too. I want to see every radio in smartphones simultaneously harnessed for synchronous and asynchronous ad hoc and mesh networking. Including TV channel information, FLDIGI,  SDR, FM and satellite downlinks..ğŸ”¥ğŸ‘ŠğŸ˜Š

@Eibriel: Same here, it said "no peers". But I'll keep trying. I want to see every smartphone, computer and router radio ad-hock  synchronizing with #Zeronet and #Retroshare by tcp/ip, mesh, etc, everywhere. For example, most smartphones come with at least 6 or 7 radios. I think my phone has about 8 or 9.. p.s. Open Source of course. :-)
Now it's saying "content.json download failed". But at least you have two peers now. ;-)

@Eibriel: Looks interesting, but it's another device radio. We already have a device. Smartphones have many radios that can go through wall and reach cell towers. My phone has about 8 radios transceivers. I would rather spend the money on a range extender. :-)
Bingo!.. Your live. :-)
@ulrichard: good point..ğŸ‘ğŸ˜€

@Eibriel:  @ulrichard: Open Garden has an interesting concept. Every month I have bandwidth and data that just goes to waste. If I could share some of it in exchange for tokens I could cash later for bandwidth and data, that could be a good incentive to mesh\share my excess..ğŸ˜€

Besides being an incredible invention. #Bitcoin seems to me just the normal evolution of money and humanity. When I first ran across #Bitcoin in the early early days I was stunned. I realized Satoshi Nakamoto had nailed it. But I struggled to wrap my brain around it, and stepped away when I lost track Satoshi around 2010. Though I have run a full node almost continuously for over 9 years now. That seemed the best I could do to support satoshi's wonderful invention. I didn't do much mining. It was all I could do to understand and keep a full node running. I'm proud of my little contribution to this wonderful invention..ğŸ‘ğŸ˜€ğŸ—½
AWESOMENESS!

We need to FORK! the #w3c. #TBL approved the #EME #DRM closed source, untouchable spyware, backdoor, and kill switch for inclusion in OUR! open web standards. This was done over the objections of the entire World. Including the United Nations. Sounds unbelievable, but it's all shamefully true. The open source community must reject the #EME and the inclusion of any other CLOSED source code are part of the OPEN! web standards. Take no prisoners..

@ulrichard: I run a full Bitcoin Core node, have for over 9 years. It's a lot more secure hot wallet, and much easier to secure. But mostly Core is how I started with Bitcoin, It's home. Electrum is nice. I like the idea of using it with Tails to create a cold storage wallet, and for offline signing. But If I remember correctly, Electrum had some security holes and vulnerabilities with respect to keyloggers as a hot wallet. It was much harder to securely setup and use as a hot wallet than Core. Plus you have to trust third party servers. With Core you don't trust, your verify. :-)

@ulrichard: "At least we can disable the crap" Yes,hopefully. But it is designed to make that hard to do, and possibly put you in potentially major international legal jeopardy if you do so. It is embedded in your browser code. It's closed source, and legally untouchable. Even in open source browsers. It's a disaster. Open Source programs must refuse to include it, and continue developing there own OPEN standards for use with encrypted media. Until then DRM must continue to be treated as the hostile, private, closed source outsider that it is. Available only as plugin by User choice, and User intervention. EME makes all Open Source programs that include it a FRAUD! It's not committees, it's the #w3c. The w3c is a FRAUD! Led by a self appointed demigod #TBL. Presiding over a group of un-elected representatives, sponsored by big corporate private special interest payoffs. The same type of shit you have going on in Washington. Only these w3c fuckers aren't elected. So the thing to do is FORK! the w3c..

@ulrichard: As I said, I do like Electrum. It's an excellent wallet and utility. But core is home. I still remember my fascination with having everything I needed in one neat, tight little program. All we needed was an internet connection. Extreme complexity made simple. Full nodes are the Guardians Of The Galaxy. If the shits ever hits the fan again, as it has done often, full nodes will carry on just as if nothing ever happened. ;-)

@ulrichard: Accepting the #w3c's corruption is not acceptable or necessary. The w3c has no legitimate authority of fiduciary. They have demonstrated that unequivocally. The w3c is just a cult of personality (#TBL), bogus. It's very easy to #Fork! the w3c. It can be done instantaneously. The #EFF and #FSF should have done it long ago. The w3c is illegitimate. No one should feel obliged to follow the w3c.

This is probably geeky nitpicking. But it really bothers me that you have to expose your private keys during wallet creation. This is a problem with many HD wallets. I would like the option and flexibility to keep my seed private and just encrypt and backup my wallet. My other geeky nitpick is short PIN codes. How hard would it be to edit a program during execution to removes the code that limits the number of retries. Then just brute force the pin in seconds. I'm probably just crazy. But that's how I think, and that's how I'd crack y'all..ğŸ˜ˆğŸ˜€
Soo true!..ğŸ‘ğŸ˜‚

@ulrichard: I agree with security professionals and Bitcoin experts like Andreas Antonopoulos that hardware wallets are probably the safest and best choice for Bitcoin key management today. And it seems that combining electrum with HW's adds a lot of utility to both. Of course I'm a geek. So I have to push it to the max. I like the idea of using an old smartphone or a cheep prepay for cold storage. And my daily driver for my spending hot wallet. Of course it would have to be done just right. But it would be highly secure and very functional. I would probably combine it with highly secure online steganography. So that even if I lost control of my phone and all my backups I could still secretly retrieve and reconstruct everything from secret online copies. Of course everything would be protected with post-quantum passwords and cryptography with various layers of audit controls. All without any physical custody or control of **MY!** wallets other than my knowledge. Sound familiar? This is how I think. :-)

@Zboy: The general public and many so-called experts are extremely vulnerable to high-tech and internet computer crime, and will be for a long time. The best we can do for them is to minimize their exposure. This is what hardware wallets do, and why they are best for most people. At least to start with. Unless you're a real! Geek, and I use Geek as a complement. The use of Electrum with HW's is in my opinion for experts. In the future I think many commercial wallets will be like my Geek wallet below. And after setup only interact with the outside world through one-way scanning of QR codes. But maybe not.  :-)

@Zboy: I should say that my proposed geek wallet never interacts with the outside world or the internet. Not even for setup. Setup files and apk's are installed from **non-writable** media like an sd card. Or from some media that is cheap enough to **destroy** after the files signatures are **verified.** The only contact with the outside world is by one way QR code scans. Honestly, I never really consider hobbyist (so-called hackers) threats to security of important things. I only think of state sponsored threats. Even though there is no reason I would be a target. It's just a more fun exercise. :-)

@Zboy: lol.. Not necessarily. Cryptography is a Beautiful! and very powerful art and science. The possibilities for privacy, concealment and anonymity are endless. Limited only by your imagination, skill and creativity. This is what makes cryptography so much **fun!**..ğŸ‘ğŸ˜ˆğŸ˜

@Zboy: @ulrichard: My Geek Wallet Protocol would probably best be called a personal Bitcoin **bank**. Rather than simply cold storage or just a secure offline wallet. If I needed a testamentary, or third party access/backup I would probably add layered rotating time and date locks + multisig's. Should you try this with time and date locks + multisig's. Probably not. But just the Geek wallet part should be fine. Highly secure and very functional. You would need to carefully research and experiment with time locks + multisig's, and the potential of negative ramifications. :-)

@klu9@zeroid.bit: The thing is, 0net is still a bit cumbersome to use. But that will improve with time. 

As 0net evolves, I can see Zeronet being used in combination with a more matured decentralized service like Retroshare.

That's not to say that Retroshare is better than 0net. It's not. They actually complement each other.

I can even see 0net used in combination with centralized and federated platforms. Giving them a new life.

Zeronet may evolve into a kind of universal hub. An internet presence for everyone. An Internet presence that's always available. That you can't take down or censor. 

A place your followers on the **FakeNet** can always find you, and update your status. So that no service can make you their Bitch!..ğŸ‘ğŸ˜…  ##Bitches!!! ğŸ˜ˆğŸ˜‚

p.s. I'm really excited to see how many of the services I can effectively Implement under Linux Deploy on my smartphone and tablet..ğŸ‘ğŸ˜€

@klu9@zeroid.bit: **Good analysis** of Zeronet. I was also shocked at how easy it was to setup on Windows. It basically does everything for you. Including taking you to set up your first Zeronet ID.

"Cumbersome" may not have been the right word to use. It's very powerful, and like Bitcoin it takes a lot of thought and exploration to fully grasp and exploit its power.

It's not a simple one-dimensional service like Facebook or Twitter. Zeronet is much more..ğŸ‘ğŸ˜€

Retroshare does an excellent job of integrating with both I2p and Tor. I also run i2p on my android phone, alongside K-9 Mail as a backup email experiment. Both work beautifully.

I2p also works beautifully with Thunderbird on Windows as a further email backup. I also like Retroshare chat app on Android. It can connect with the windows clients through I2p or Orbot, or without.

See, I warned you I was a geek. A real one..ğŸ˜‚

I think starting with Tor was a good decision. Tor is more mature and has wider adoption. We can always add i2p at a later time, when Tor is working smoothly with Zeronet.

I haven't checked lately. But I suspect people are still having problems posting pictures with Tor Browser Bundle.

But you're right. A centralized point of failure can be compromised in many ways. Including becoming a Central Intelligence point of spying..ğŸ˜‚

@Lostfile: I don't know which one is more decentralized. But I2p is more of a closed system. That's both a strength and a weakness. I use both a lot for different things.

I have my doubts about the security of Tor's anonymity. But when it comes to important security the wise man is always thoughtful and paranoid.

On the other hand, Tor is excellent at bypassing firewalls and other obstructions. I use i2p with K9-Mail and Thunderbird on my Android and Windows laptop as an email backup.

It works very well. And I also use i2p and Tor simultaneously with Retroshare. And that also works well too. But I2p is more complex to setup and configure properly. ğŸ˜€
